urn:contentItem:5V6X-P3V1-JD34-V21J-00000-00Fire puts our communities under siege2019-01-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:48ZLexisNexisFire puts our communities under siegeCarly Werner

THE Northern Grampians Complex fire was one of the largest in Wimmera history.

Wednesday January 15, 2014 marked the region's third consecutive day of extreme heat. As a storm band crossed the Wimmera, lightning strikes sparked multiple fires.

At 6pm, the first of several fires were reported in the northern Grampians. Crews contained some, but two continued to burn overnight.

By mid-afternoon the next day, these fires had joined. Aircraft and ground crews worked to protect houses as the fire entered private property late in the day.

That night, a wind shift caused the fire to spread towards the Wartook and Brimpaen areas. It was during this period that one woman lost her life, which authorities later stated was the result of a medical issue. Houses and farmland were destroyed.

On Friday, Dadswells Bridge and Halls Gap were under threat, with the latter's residents urged to evacuate.

The weather pushed the fire south, and by this point there were three distinct fire fronts. An earlier-than-predicted wind change meant the fire did not reach Halls Gap, but came within two kilometres north-west of the town.

Weather conditions calmed on the Saturday. It took another three weeks of continual patrol and blacking out before the fire was declared under control.

The fire damaged 135 structures, 32 dwellings - including 19 primary residences, and more than 6000 hectares of private land. More than 5000 stock and 300 kilometres of fencing were lost. The fire's perimeter was 257 kilometres, and it covered 55,100 hectares.

At its peak, 180 Forest Fire Management crew, 440 Country Fire Authority crew, seven graders, six bulldozers, four fixed-wing bombers and six helitak helicopters fought the inferno.

urn:contentItem:5V7S-N661-JD34-V2PJ-00000-00'We want a shift in behaviour'2019-01-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:48ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4'We want a shift in behaviour'Ben Hopkins

The fact that only a quarter of Victorian national park users know campfires have to be extinguished with water is a 'deep concern' for CFA District 15 operations manager Brett Boatman.

In a Parks Victoria survey, 1000 Victorians were asked whether a campfire should be put out with water or covered with soil or sand, with 74 per cent selecting the latter, incorrect answer.

"We want a shift in behaviour," Mr Boatman said.

"We need people to be prepared and to know exactly what they are doing so their small camp fire doesn't become a major issue for the rest of the community.

"We are all about harm minimisation."

The campfire site should be cool to touch before being left unattended.

As the state's temperatures remain high for another week, rangers have been targeting popular campsites, reminding visitors of their responsibilities.

The survey also found that only about half of park users know where and when they are allowed to light a campfire.

This is only allowed in designated fireplaces and not on total fire ban days.

"The regulations are clear on what fires you can have on a total fire ban day.

"You can have a small fire for warmth and for cooking, but after you are done you need to make sure the area is safe for the next person."

In November of last year it took a combined effort from the CFA and Forest Fire Victoria, including two fire-bombing aircrafts from Stawell to control a fire as it burned through 10 hectares of state forest land.

It is believed the blaze was caused by an incorrectly extinguished campfire.

urn:contentItem:5VY0-3X31-JD34-V125-00000-00Clean up operation to clear illegal campsite stretches for two days2019-04-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:48ZLexisNexisClean up operation to clear illegal campsite stretches for two daysMonique Patterson

FURNITURE, white goods and household rubbish left by a group of people who were illegally camping in the Cobboboonee Forest has been removed.

Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) forest management and roading officer Wes Burns said contractors removed almost 140 cubic metres of rubbish from the site over a number of days.

"Rubbish removed included furniture, white goods, household rubbish and camping gear," Mr Burns said.

"FFMVic officers inspected the site to identify concealed traps and hazards to ensure these were also removed during the clean up."

Mr Burns said crews would start rehabilitation works to restore the site shortly.

Mr Burns said illegally dumped rubbish affected the environment and presented safety issues.

Read more: Victorian Tent Embassy Alliance member will use spear to protect elders if threatened at Cobboboonee forest campsite

Furniture and rubbish has been left strewn in the Cobboboonee forest after a group living there moved on

"While this situation relates to a group illegally occupying the forest, rubbish being dumped on public land is not a new issue in the district," Mr Burns said.

"Our crews spend hundreds of hours every year cleaning up litter that has been irresponsibly dumped, instead of being disposed of correctly."

Mr Burns said the authority would rather spend time and money on upgrades for forests and parks.

"Help us ensure these spaces are respected and used responsibly and report any suspicious behaviour or littering directly to EPA Victoria on 1300 372 842," he said.

Infringements for litter related offences range from $322 to $1934, while the maximum penalty amount ranges from $3223 to $9671 if an offender is prosecuted in court.

urn:contentItem:5XMY-HTC1-JD3N-52GM-00000-00Bulldozer driver killed as winds fan fires2019-12-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:48ZLexisNexisTHENATIONPg. 7Bulldozer driver killed as winds fan firesKIERAN GAIR, MARK SCHLIEBS

Exhausted fire crews are battling to save homes on the NSW south coast as fierce winds fan a fire that doubled in size in less than 24 hours and shut off a network of critical escape routes in nearby coastal communities.

The out-of-control fire northwest of Batemans Bay had burnt across more than 16,000ha and destroyed at least one home.

The new fire emergency erupted as it was revealed a man had been killed when his bulldozer rolled down an embankment while he was helping firefighters in Victoria's Gippsland.

The 69-year-old, who was a contractor for the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, died while creating earth breaks to help fight a blaze at Gelantipy, 400km northeast of Melbourne, on Saturday.

An emergency warning was -issued on Monday for the fire at Currowan, near Batemans Bay. The Princes Highway was closed between Termeil and the Kings Highway turnoff, cutting access to coastal commun-ities in the area.

The Rural Fire Service NSW warned those living in areas between Kioloa and North Durras, including Depot Beach, Pebbly Beach, -Pretty Beach and Bawley Point, that it was too late to leave. There was also a significant amount of smoke in the area.

Rural Fire Service deputy commissioner Rob Rogers said: "It has been really tough. The winds are very strong and it's very dry and there's no humidity in the landscape, so that's causing firefighters a lot of problems." Two million hectares of NSW land have been burnt since July in more than 7000 fires that have raged in the "most challenging bushfire season ever". Six people have died while 673 homes have been destroyed to date.

In Victoria, police said the bulldozer-driving contractor died when his vehicle rolled over.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's chief fire officer Chris Hardman said the man was a support worker. "It's the worst possible day we could have as a team; personally, it's just a horrible, hollow feeling," he said. "We've lost somebody that's come to help us and I hope and pray that we don't lose any more people." The man was from the east Gippsland region and had helped fire crews in the past.

Victoria Police inspector Mark Edwards told ABC radio that the man died at the scene. "It's an -absolute tragedy. For anybody who is helping the community fighting fires, it's just horrendous," he said.Additional reporting: AAP
